segment.source: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++
segment.target: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++

segment.source: This article shows how to use C++ to create a Windows Runtime component, which is a DLL that's callable from a Universal Windows app that's built by using JavaScript—or C#, Visual Basic, or C++.
segment.target: This article shows how to use C++ to create a Windows Runtime component, which is a DLL that's callable from a Universal Windows app that's built by using JavaScript—or C#, Visual Basic, or C++.

segment.source: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++
segment.target: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

segment.source: This article shows how to use C++ to create a Windows Runtime component, which is a DLL that's callable from a Universal Windows app that's built by using JavaScript—or C#, Visual Basic, or C++.
segment.target: This article shows how to use C++ to create a Windows Runtime component, which is a DLL that's callable from a Universal Windows app that's built by using JavaScript—or C#, Visual Basic, or C++.

segment.source: Here are several reasons for building such a component:
segment.target: Here are several reasons for building such a component:

segment.source: To get the performance advantage of C++ in complex or computationally intensive operations.
segment.target: To get the performance advantage of C++ in complex or computationally intensive operations.

segment.source: To reuse code that's already written and tested.
segment.target: To reuse code that's already written and tested.

segment.source: When you build a solution that contains a JavaScript or .NET project, and a Windows Runtime component project, the JavaScript project files and the compiled DLL are merged into one package, which you can debug locally in the simulator or remotely on a tethered device.
segment.target: When you build a solution that contains a JavaScript or .NET project, and a Windows Runtime component project, the JavaScript project files and the compiled DLL are merged into one package, which you can debug locally in the simulator or remotely on a tethered device.

segment.source: You can also distribute just the component project as an Extension SDK.
segment.target: You can also distribute just the component project as an Extension SDK.

segment.source: For more information, see Creating a Software Development Kit.
segment.target: For more information, see Creating a Software Development Kit.

segment.source: In general, when you code your C++ component, use the regular C++ library and built-in types, except at the abstract binary interface (ABI) boundary where you are passing data to and from code in another .winmd package.
segment.target: In general, when you code your C++ component, use the regular C++ library and built-in types, except at the abstract binary interface (ABI) boundary where you are passing data to and from code in another .winmd package.

segment.source: There, use Windows Runtime types and the special syntax that Visual C++ supports for creating and manipulating those types.
segment.target: There, use Windows Runtime types and the special syntax that Visual C++ supports for creating and manipulating those types.

segment.source: In addition, in your Visual C++ code, use types such as delegate and event to implement events that can be fired from your component and handled in JavaScript, Visual Basic, or C#.
segment.target: In addition, in your Visual C++ code, use types such as delegate and event to implement events that can be fired from your component and handled in JavaScript, Visual Basic, or C#.

segment.source: For more information about the new Visual C++ syntax, see Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information about the new Visual C++ syntax, see Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).

segment.source: Casing and naming rules
segment.target: Casing and naming rules

segment.source: JavaScript
segment.target: JavaScript

segment.source: JavaScript is case-sensitive.
segment.target: JavaScript is case-sensitive.

segment.source: Therefore, you must follow these casing conventions:
segment.target: Therefore, you must follow these casing conventions:

segment.source: When you reference C++ namespaces and classes, use the same casing that's used on the C++ side.
segment.target: When you reference C++ namespaces and classes, use the same casing that's used on the C++ side.

segment.source: When you call methods, use camel casing even if the method name is capitalized on the C++ side.
segment.target: When you call methods, use camel casing even if the method name is capitalized on the C++ side.

segment.source: For example, a C++ method GetDate() must be called from JavaScript as getDate().
segment.target: For example, a C++ method GetDate() must be called from JavaScript as getDate().

segment.source: An activatable class name and namespace name can't contain UNICODE characters.
segment.target: An activatable class name and namespace name can't contain UNICODE characters.

segment.source: .NET
segment.target: .NET

segment.source: The .NET languages follow their normal casing rules.
segment.target: The .NET languages follow their normal casing rules.

segment.source: Instantiating the object
segment.target: Instantiating the object

segment.source: Only Windows Runtime types can be passed across the ABI boundary.
segment.target: Only Windows Runtime types can be passed across the ABI boundary.

segment.source: The compiler will raise an error if the component has a type like std::wstring as a return type or parameter in a public method.
segment.target: The compiler will raise an error if the component has a type like std::wstring as a return type or parameter in a public method.

segment.source: The Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) built-in types include the usual scalars such as int and double, and also their typedef equivalents int32, float64, and so on.For more information, see Type System (C++/CX).
segment.target: The Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) built-in types include the usual scalars such as int and double, and also their typedef equivalents int32, float64, and so on.For more information, see Type System (C++/CX).

segment.source: C++ built-in types, library types, and Windows Runtime types
segment.target: C++ built-in types, library types, and Windows Runtime types

segment.source: An activatable class (also known as a ref class) is one that can be instantiated from another language such as JavaScript, C# or Visual Basic.
segment.target: An activatable class (also known as a ref class) is one that can be instantiated from another language such as JavaScript, C# or Visual Basic.

segment.source: To be consumable from another language, a component must contain at least one activatable class.
segment.target: To be consumable from another language, a component must contain at least one activatable class.

segment.source: A Windows Runtime component can contain multiple public activatable classes as well as additional classes that are known only internally to the component.
segment.target: A Windows Runtime component can contain multiple public activatable classes as well as additional classes that are known only internally to the component.

segment.source: Apply the WebHostHidden attribute to C++ types that are not intended to be visible to JavaScript.
segment.target: Apply the WebHostHidden attribute to C++ types that are not intended to be visible to JavaScript.

segment.source: All public classes must reside in the same root namespace which has the same name as the component metadata file.
segment.target: All public classes must reside in the same root namespace which has the same name as the component metadata file.

segment.source: For example, a class that's named A.B.C.MyClass can be instantiated only if it's defined in a metadata file that's named A.winmd or A.B.winmd or A.B.C.winmd.
segment.target: For example, a class that's named A.B.C.MyClass can be instantiated only if it's defined in a metadata file that's named A.winmd or A.B.winmd or A.B.C.winmd.

segment.source: The name of the DLL is not required to match the .winmd file name.
segment.target: The name of the DLL is not required to match the .winmd file name.

segment.source: Client code creates an instance of the component by using the new (New in Visual Basic) keyword just as for any class.
segment.target: Client code creates an instance of the component by using the new (New in Visual Basic) keyword just as for any class.

segment.source: An activatable class must be declared as public ref class sealed.
segment.target: An activatable class must be declared as public ref class sealed.

segment.source: The ref class keyword tells the compiler to create the class as a Windows Runtime compatible type, and the sealed keyword specifies that the class cannot be inherited.
segment.target: The ref class keyword tells the compiler to create the class as a Windows Runtime compatible type, and the sealed keyword specifies that the class cannot be inherited.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime does not currently support a generalized inheritance model; a limited inheritance model supports creation of custom XAML controls.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime does not currently support a generalized inheritance model; a limited inheritance model supports creation of custom XAML controls.

segment.source: For more information, see Ref classes and structs (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information, see Ref classes and structs (C++/CX).

segment.source: For C++, all the numeric primitives are defined in the default namespace.
segment.target: For C++, all the numeric primitives are defined in the default namespace.

segment.source: The Platform namespace contains C++ classes that are specific to the Windows Runtime type system.
segment.target: The Platform namespace contains C++ classes that are specific to the Windows Runtime type system.

segment.source: These include Platform::String class and Platform::Object class.
segment.target: These include Platform::String class and Platform::Object class.

segment.source: The concrete collection types such as Platform::Collections::Map class and Platform::Collections::Vector class are defined in the Platform::Collections namespace.
segment.target: The concrete collection types such as Platform::Collections::Map class and Platform::Collections::Vector class are defined in the Platform::Collections namespace.

segment.source: The public interfaces that these types implement are defined in Windows::Foundation::Collections Namespace (C++/CX).
segment.target: The public interfaces that these types implement are defined in Windows::Foundation::Collections Namespace (C++/CX).

segment.source: It is these interface types that are consumed by JavaScript, C# and Visual Basic.
segment.target: It is these interface types that are consumed by JavaScript, C# and Visual Basic.

segment.source: For more information, see Type System (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information, see Type System (C++/CX).

segment.source: Method that returns a value of built-in type
segment.target: Method that returns a value of built-in type

segment.source: Method that returns a custom value struct
segment.target: Method that returns a custom value struct

segment.source: To pass user-defined value structs across the ABI, define a JavaScript object that has the same members as the value struct that's defined in C++.
segment.target: To pass user-defined value structs across the ABI, define a JavaScript object that has the same members as the value struct that's defined in C++.

segment.source: You can then pass that object as an argument to a C++ method so that the object is implicitly converted to the C++ type.
segment.target: You can then pass that object as an argument to a C++ method so that the object is implicitly converted to the C++ type.

segment.source: Another approach is to define a class that implements IPropertySet (not shown).
segment.target: Another approach is to define a class that implements IPropertySet (not shown).

segment.source: In the .NET languages, you just create a variable of the type that's defined in the C++ component.
segment.target: In the .NET languages, you just create a variable of the type that's defined in the C++ component.

segment.source: Overloaded Methods
segment.target: Overloaded Methods

segment.source: A C++ public ref class can contain overloaded methods, but JavaScript has limited ability to differentiate overloaded methods.
segment.target: A C++ public ref class can contain overloaded methods, but JavaScript has limited ability to differentiate overloaded methods.

segment.source: For example, it can tell the difference between these signatures:
segment.target: For example, it can tell the difference between these signatures:

segment.source: But it can’t tell the difference between these:
segment.target: But it can’t tell the difference between these:

segment.source: In ambiguous cases, you can ensure that JavaScript always calls a specific overload by applying the Windows::Foundation::Metadata::DefaultOverload attribute to the method signature in the header file.
segment.target: In ambiguous cases, you can ensure that JavaScript always calls a specific overload by applying the Windows::Foundation::Metadata::DefaultOverload attribute to the method signature in the header file.

segment.source: This JavaScript always calls the attributed overload:
segment.target: This JavaScript always calls the attributed overload:

segment.source: .NET
segment.target: .NET

segment.source: The .NET languages recognize overloads in a C++ ref class just as in any .NET Framework class.
segment.target: The .NET languages recognize overloads in a C++ ref class just as in any .NET Framework class.

segment.source: DateTime
segment.target: DateTime

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, a Windows::Foundation::DateTime object is just a 64-bit signed integer that represents the number of 100-nanosecond intervals either before or after January 1, 1601.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime, a Windows::Foundation::DateTime object is just a 64-bit signed integer that represents the number of 100-nanosecond intervals either before or after January 1, 1601.

segment.source: There are no methods on a Windows:Foundation::DateTime object.
segment.target: There are no methods on a Windows:Foundation::DateTime object.

segment.source: Instead, each language projects the DateTime in the way that is native to that language: the Date object in JavaScript and the System.DateTime and System.DateTimeOffset types in the .NET Framework.
segment.target: Instead, each language projects the DateTime in the way that is native to that language: the Date object in JavaScript and the System.DateTime and System.DateTimeOffset types in the .NET Framework.

segment.source: When you pass a DateTime value from C++ to JavaScript, JavaScript accepts it as a Date object and displays it by default as a long-form date string.
segment.target: When you pass a DateTime value from C++ to JavaScript, JavaScript accepts it as a Date object and displays it by default as a long-form date string.

segment.source: When a .NET language passes a System.DateTime to a C++ component, the method accepts it as a Windows::Foundation::DateTime.
segment.target: When a .NET language passes a System.DateTime to a C++ component, the method accepts it as a Windows::Foundation::DateTime.

segment.source: When the component passes a Windows::Foundation::DateTime to a .NET Framework method, the Framework method accepts it as a DateTimeOffset.
segment.target: When the component passes a Windows::Foundation::DateTime to a .NET Framework method, the Framework method accepts it as a DateTimeOffset.

segment.source: Collections and arrays
segment.target: Collections and arrays

segment.source: Collections are always passed across the ABI boundary as handles to Windows Runtime types such as Windows::Foundation::Collections::IVector^ and Windows::Foundation::Collections::IMap^.
segment.target: Collections are always passed across the ABI boundary as handles to Windows Runtime types such as Windows::Foundation::Collections::IVector^ and Windows::Foundation::Collections::IMap^.

segment.source: For example, if you return a handle to a Platform::Collections::Map, it implicitly converts to a Windows::Foundation::Collections::IMap^.
segment.target: For example, if you return a handle to a Platform::Collections::Map, it implicitly converts to a Windows::Foundation::Collections::IMap^.

segment.source: The collection interfaces are defined in a namespace that's separate from the C++ classes that provide the concrete implementations.
segment.target: The collection interfaces are defined in a namespace that's separate from the C++ classes that provide the concrete implementations.

segment.source: JavaScript and .NET languages consume the interfaces.
segment.target: JavaScript and .NET languages consume the interfaces.

segment.source: For more information, see Collections (C++/CX) and Array and WriteOnlyArray (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information, see Collections (C++/CX) and Array and WriteOnlyArray (C++/CX).

segment.source: Passing IVector
segment.target: Passing IVector

segment.source: The .NET languages see IVectorT as IListT.
segment.target: The .NET languages see IVectorT as IListT.

segment.source: Passing IMap
segment.target: Passing IMap

segment.source: The .NET languages see IMap and IDictionaryK, V.
segment.target: The .NET languages see IMap and IDictionaryK, V.

segment.source: Properties
segment.target: Properties

segment.source: A public ref class in Visual C++ component extensions exposes public data members as properties, by using the property keyword.
segment.target: A public ref class in Visual C++ component extensions exposes public data members as properties, by using the property keyword.

segment.source: The concept is identical to .NET Framework properties.
segment.target: The concept is identical to .NET Framework properties.

segment.source: A trivial property resembles a data member because its functionality is implicit.
segment.target: A trivial property resembles a data member because its functionality is implicit.

segment.source: A non-trivial property has explicit get and set accessors and a named private variable that's the "backing store" for the value.
segment.target: A non-trivial property has explicit get and set accessors and a named private variable that's the "backing store" for the value.

segment.source: In this example, the private member variable \_propertyAValue is the backing store for PropertyA.
segment.target: In this example, the private member variable \_propertyAValue is the backing store for PropertyA.

segment.source: A property can fire an event when its value changes, and a client app can register to receive that event.
segment.target: A property can fire an event when its value changes, and a client app can register to receive that event.

segment.source: The .NET languages access properties on a native C++ object just as they would on a .NET Framework object.
segment.target: The .NET languages access properties on a native C++ object just as they would on a .NET Framework object.

segment.source: Delegates and events
segment.target: Delegates and events

segment.source: A delegate is a Windows Runtime type that represents a function object.
segment.target: A delegate is a Windows Runtime type that represents a function object.

segment.source: You can use delegates in connection with events, callbacks, and asynchronous method calls to specify an action to be performed later.
segment.target: You can use delegates in connection with events, callbacks, and asynchronous method calls to specify an action to be performed later.

segment.source: Like a function object, the delegate provides type-safety by enabling the compiler to verify the return type and parameter types of the function.
segment.target: Like a function object, the delegate provides type-safety by enabling the compiler to verify the return type and parameter types of the function.

segment.source: The declaration of a delegate resembles a function signature, the implementation resembles a class definition, and the invocation resembles a function invocation.
segment.target: The declaration of a delegate resembles a function signature, the implementation resembles a class definition, and the invocation resembles a function invocation.

segment.source: Adding an event listener
segment.target: Adding an event listener

segment.source: You can use the event keyword to declare a public member of a specified delegate type.
segment.target: You can use the event keyword to declare a public member of a specified delegate type.

segment.source: Client code subscribes to the event by using the standard mechanisms that are provided in the particular language.
segment.target: Client code subscribes to the event by using the standard mechanisms that are provided in the particular language.

segment.source: This example uses the same C++ code as for the previous properties section.
segment.target: This example uses the same C++ code as for the previous properties section.

segment.source: In the .NET languages, subscribing to an event in a C++ component is the same as subscribing to an event in a .NET Framework class:
segment.target: In the .NET languages, subscribing to an event in a C++ component is the same as subscribing to an event in a .NET Framework class:

segment.source: Adding multiple event listeners for one event
segment.target: Adding multiple event listeners for one event

segment.source: JavaScript has an addEventListener method that enables multiple handlers to subscribe to a single event.
segment.target: JavaScript has an addEventListener method that enables multiple handlers to subscribe to a single event.

segment.source: In C#, any number of event handlers can subscribe to the event by using the += operator as shown in the previous example.
segment.target: In C#, any number of event handlers can subscribe to the event by using the += operator as shown in the previous example.

segment.source: Enums
segment.target: Enums

segment.source: A Windows Runtime enum in C++ is declared by using public class enum; it resembles a scoped enum in standard C++.
segment.target: A Windows Runtime enum in C++ is declared by using public class enum; it resembles a scoped enum in standard C++.

segment.source: Enum values are passed between C++ and JavaScript as integers.
segment.target: Enum values are passed between C++ and JavaScript as integers.

segment.source: You can optionally declare a JavaScript object that contains the same named values as the C++ enum and use it as follows.
segment.target: You can optionally declare a JavaScript object that contains the same named values as the C++ enum and use it as follows.

segment.source: Both C# and Visual Basic have language support for enums.
segment.target: Both C# and Visual Basic have language support for enums.

segment.source: These languages see a C++ public enum class just as they would see a .NET Framework enum.
segment.target: These languages see a C++ public enum class just as they would see a .NET Framework enum.

segment.source: Asynchronous methods
segment.target: Asynchronous methods

segment.source: To consume asynchronous methods that are exposed by other Windows Runtime objects, use the task Class (Concurrency Runtime).
segment.target: To consume asynchronous methods that are exposed by other Windows Runtime objects, use the task Class (Concurrency Runtime).

segment.source: For more information, see and Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime).
segment.target: For more information, see and Task Parallelism (Concurrency Runtime).

segment.source: To implement asynchronous methods in C++, use the create\_async function that's defined in ppltasks.h.
segment.target: To implement asynchronous methods in C++, use the create\_async function that's defined in ppltasks.h.

segment.source: For more information, see Creating Asynchronous Operations in C++ for Windows Store Apps.
segment.target: For more information, see Creating Asynchronous Operations in C++ for Windows Store Apps.

segment.source: For an example, see Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C#.
segment.target: For an example, see Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C#.

segment.source: The .NET languages consume C++ asynchronous methods just as they would any asynchronous method that's defined in the .NET Framework.
segment.target: The .NET languages consume C++ asynchronous methods just as they would any asynchronous method that's defined in the .NET Framework.

segment.source: Exceptions
segment.target: Exceptions

segment.source: You can throw any exception type that's defined by the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: You can throw any exception type that's defined by the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: You cannot derive custom types from any Windows Runtime exception type.
segment.target: You cannot derive custom types from any Windows Runtime exception type.

segment.source: However, you can throw COMException and provide a custom HRESULT that can be accessed by the code that catches the exception.
segment.target: However, you can throw COMException and provide a custom HRESULT that can be accessed by the code that catches the exception.

segment.source: There's no way to specify a custom Message in a COMException.
segment.target: There's no way to specify a custom Message in a COMException.

segment.source: Debugging tips
segment.target: Debugging tips

segment.source: When you debug a JavaScript solution that has a component DLL, you can set the debugger to enable either stepping through script, or stepping through native code in the component, but not both at the same time.
segment.target: When you debug a JavaScript solution that has a component DLL, you can set the debugger to enable either stepping through script, or stepping through native code in the component, but not both at the same time.

segment.source: To change the setting, select the JavaScript project node in Solution Explorer and then choose Properties, Debugging, Debugger Type.
segment.target: To change the setting, select the JavaScript project node in Solution Explorer and then choose Properties, Debugging, Debugger Type.

segment.source: Be sure to select appropriate capabilities in the package designer.
segment.target: Be sure to select appropriate capabilities in the package designer.

segment.source: For example, if you are attempting to open an image file in the user's Pictures library by using the Windows Runtime APIs, be sure to select the Pictures Library check box in the Capabilities pane of the manifest designer.
segment.target: For example, if you are attempting to open an image file in the user's Pictures library by using the Windows Runtime APIs, be sure to select the Pictures Library check box in the Capabilities pane of the manifest designer.

segment.source: If your JavaScript code doesn't seem to be recognizing the public properties or methods in the component, make sure that in JavaScript you are using camel casing.
segment.target: If your JavaScript code doesn't seem to be recognizing the public properties or methods in the component, make sure that in JavaScript you are using camel casing.

segment.source: For example, the LogCalc C++ method must be referenced as logCalc in JavaScript.
segment.target: For example, the LogCalc C++ method must be referenced as logCalc in JavaScript.

segment.source: If you remove a C++ Windows Runtime component project from a solution, you must also manually remove the project reference from the JavaScript project.
segment.target: If you remove a C++ Windows Runtime component project from a solution, you must also manually remove the project reference from the JavaScript project.

segment.source: Failure to do so prevents subsequent debug or build operations.
segment.target: Failure to do so prevents subsequent debug or build operations.

segment.source: If necessary, you can then add an assembly reference to the DLL.
segment.target: If necessary, you can then add an assembly reference to the DLL.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C
segment.target: Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C
